choices.text: State Medical Council
National Medical Commission
Medical Council of India

questions.text: Dr. Singh, a cardiologist in New Delhi, is under investigation after several complaints from patients regarding his prescription practices, which allegedly violate the nationally recognized medical code of ethics. He is accused of overprescribing medications in exchange for incentives from a pharmaceutical company. In the context of medical regulation in India, which authority(ies) is/are primarily responsible for issuing a formal warning to Dr. Singh?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) State Medical Council

 

Option B:

 

In India, professional conduct and ethics in medicine are regulated by state Medical Council. The SMC handle local medical registration and can take action against ethical breaches within their respective states. SMC issues the warning notices to physicians for professional misconduct.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Central Government typically does not get involved in issuing warnings for ethical violations at the level of individual medical practitioners.

 

Option C. While NMC is involved in drafting a general list of practices which can be considered unethical and lead to warning but they do not typically issue warning to individual doctors. It is issue by SMC

 

Option D. While the Medical Council of India (MCI) was replaced by the National Medical Commission (NMC) in 2019, sets and enforces ethical standards for all of India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The state medical council is responsible for the issuing a warning notice to a physician for violating the medical code of ethics.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. p25

choices.text: Filing an FIR against the patient for not paying the fee
Res ipsa loquitor

questions.text: A neurosurgeon at a private hospital has a standing agreement with a referring primary care physician. For every patient referred to the neurosurgeon, the primary care physician receives a certain percentage of the surgical fee. This arrangement has come under scrutiny during a routine audit by the healthcare regulatory authority. What is this controversial practice called?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dichotomy

 

Option B:

 

The term "dichotomy" specifically refers to the practice of fee-splitting in the medical field, where a physician receives a portion of the fees from another physician to whom they refer patients. This practice is considered unethical because it could potentially influence the physician's judgment regarding the patient's best interest.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. "Conduct money" - It is the money given or paid to a witness in civil cases to meet the expenses towards attending the court. In civil cases, conduct money is paid to the doctor at the time of serving the summons. If the money is not paid or the doctor feels that the sum paid is inadequate, he can inform the court accordingly.

 

Option C. Filing a "FIR" (First Information Report) against a patient for not paying a fee is a legal term related to law enforcement.

 

Option D. "Res Ipsa loquitor" is a legal term used in tort law that applies when the cause of an injury is presumed to be negligence by the principle that certain events may not happen in the absence of negligence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dichotomy - is defined as Receiving or giving commission or other benefits to a professional colleague or chemist or dentist or manufacturer.  It is a kind of PROFESSIONAL MISCONDUCT and can be punished by the State Medical Council. The punishment can be:

 

  • Warning
  • Suspension
  • Penal erasure (professional death sentence).

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. p646

choices.text: Calculated risk doctrine

questions.text: A medical resident is being tutored on the legal defenses available in cases of alleged criminal negligence. The resident is presented with a scenario where a patient has suffered adverse effects following a procedure, and the medical team's actions are under scrutiny. Which of the following is NOT considered a valid legal defense against charges of criminal negligence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Contributory negligence

 

Option B:

 

Both patient and doctor are at fault. A defense for doctor only in civil negligence, but the onus to proof will lie on Doctor.

 

E.g. Patient comes with knee pain and he is advised to take 1000mg PCM every 4 hrly for 1 week. Here the doctor is negligent for giving such a high dose. The patient instead of taking for 1 week takes it for 1 month – here both the doctor and patient are negligent. Here 2 things can occur:

 

  1. Mild injury (e.g. Gastritis)– Will be a case of civil negligence. Doctor can take contributory negligence of a patient as a defense against a case of civil negligence filed against him. But, the burden to proof, that the patient was also negligent, lies with the doctor.
  2. Major injury (e.g. Gastric perforation)– Will be a case of criminal negligence. Contributory negligence of a patient is not a defense for the doctor here. Hence the doctor can be punished even if the patient was also at fault.

 

Two Doctrines are related to contributory negligence –

 

  1. Last clear chance Doctrine”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Doctor” still had the last chance to avoid complications. Here the doctor cannot take the defense.
  2. Avoidable consequences rule”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Patient” had the last chance to avoid complications by timely informing the doctor. Here doctor can take the defense

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Calculated risk doctrine - This doctrine is an important defense to any doctor sued for professional negligence, who can produce expert evidence or statistics to show that the accepted method of treatment he employed had unavoidable risks. This can be a defense in criminal negligence if it can be shown that the risks were known, considered, and consented to.

 

Option C. Novus actus interveniens - if proven, can absolve a defendant from liability in criminal negligence if an intervening event is the direct cause of the harm. A person is responsible not only for his actions, but also for the logical consequences of those actions. This principle applies to cases of assault and accidental injury.

 

Option D. Medical misadventure may be considered a defense if the harm was not due to the defendant’s negligence but rather an unforeseen medical complication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct, or absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient, or his personal attendant, which combined with the doctor's negligence, contributed to the injury complained of, as a direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 39

choices.text: Indefinitely, with no time limit

questions.text: As part of a hospital administration and management course, you are learning about the retention policies for medical records. The instructor emphasizes the importance of understanding the duration for which different types of medical records must be preserved. For how long are medicolegal case records typically required to be kept?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 10 years

 

Explanation:

 

Option C:

 

It is generally advised that Medicolegal records be retained for a substantial period to ensure they are available if legal issues arise. While the exact duration may vary by jurisdiction, a common practice is to preserve these records for at least 10 years.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maintenance of medical records-

 

MEDICAL RECORDS

 

  1. Duration of retention of records –
    • Digital Records – 10 years
    • Hard copy – 
      • OPD patients: 3 years
      • Indoor patients: 3 years
      • Medico-Legal Case: 10 years
  2. Time to provide records – within 3 days
  3. What if records not maintained – punished for infamous conduct

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 49

choices.text: A convicted prisoner can be examined without consent
Covid-19 vaccination cannot be carried out without consent
If a person had given consent for organ donation and after death, the legal heir does not give consent, the organ donation cannot be done
Consent from legal heir of dead body is required during medicolegal autopsy

questions.text: During a medical ethics class, the topic of consent and its legal implications in various scenarios is discussed. A scenario-based question is posed to you to identify the incorrect application of consent according to general ethical guidelines and laws?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Consent from the legal heir of a deceased is required for conducting a medicolegal autopsy

 

Option D:

 

In medicolegal cases, an autopsy is conducted to determine the cause of death, particularly in situations where foul play or criminal activity is suspected. The consent of the deceased's legal heir is not required for such an autopsy to proceed. Once the inquest papers are prepared by the investigating officer, the autopsy is mandated by law to be conducted without delay to aid the investigation.

 

Rules of Consent –

 

  • Consent is necessary for every medical examination.
  • Any procedure such as blood transfusion and collection of blood requires expressed consent.
  • A woman should not be examined without her consent in medicolegal cases like rape, abortion, etc.
  • Consent of spouse is not required for the medical treatment while for contraceptives, sterilization, and artificial insemination, consent of both husband and wife should be obtained. For MTP, the consent of the husband is not mandatory, but good to take, otherwise it can be a ground for divorce.
  • A prisoner should be treated without his consent.
  • Doctor can examine accused person of a sexual assault case on request of investigating officer, even by using reasonable force, if the person is arrested/ under custody of police or magistrate (53 CrPC).
  • Pathological autopsy-consent of relatives required
  • Medico-legal autopsy-consent of relatives not required

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Prisoners have certain rights, but in specific circumstances, such as the preservation of safety and order, they may be examined without consent.

 

Option B. As per supreme court judgment covid-19 vaccine cannot be given without the consent.

 

Option C. Even if a person has given prior consent for his / her organ donation prior to death, still the consent of legal heir is required after death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CONSENT means voluntary agreement, compliance, or permission. Consent in Emergency- In case of life-threatening emergency, if no one is available then no consent required as per 92 IPC

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 50

choices.text: Res ipsa loquitor

questions.text: Dr. Kavita, a recent medical school graduate, is attending a workshop on medical law. The presenter discusses a case where a patient alleged civil negligence against a physician, but the lawsuit was not filed within the legally designated period. Dr. Kavita is asked to identify the legal doctrine that bars the case from being opened after this period. Which term correctly identifies this doctrine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Res indicata

 

Option A:

 

Res indicata - A suit for damages for negligence against the doctor should be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed as being beyond the period of limitation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Res judicata (Doctrine of Double Jeopardy) -  If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a Court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient. The patient will not be allowed to contest the same question in another proceeding between himself and the doctor on the same set of facts. Only an appeal can be made.

 

Option C. Res ipsa loquitor - Ordinarily, the professional negligence of a physician must be proved in Court by the expert evidence of another physician. The patient need not prove negligence in case where the rule of res ipsa loquit0r applies, which means "the thing or fact speaks for itself". The patient has to merely state what according to him was an act of negligence.

 

Option D. Res vires - No such term.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Defenses against medical negligence

 

  1. No duty owned to patient
  2. Duty discharged as per standards 
  3. Therapeutic misadventure (medical maloccurence) .
  4. Res Indicata (Limitation period of 2 years in case of civil case)
  5. Error of judgement 
  6. Res Judicata - (“Doctrine of double jeopardy)
  7. Volunti nonfit injuria
  8. Contributory negligence

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 46

questions.text: A medical ethics debate is taking place among residents regarding the legality of euthanasia across different jurisdictions. Dr. Nair, a resident in the program, is presenting a case study of a terminally ill patient who wishes to opt for euthanasia. He discusses the legal status of this practice around the world and poses a question about where it is legally sanctioned. In which country is euthanasia legally recognized as a permissible end-of-life option?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Netherlands

 

Option D:

 

The Netherlands was one of the first countries to legalize euthanasia under strict conditions, with the Termination of Life on Request and Assisted Suicide (Review Procedures) Act coming into effect in April 2002.

 

This legislation allows physicians to perform euthanasia if certain criteria are met, including:

 

  1. The disease is incurable.
  2. The patient's suffering is unbearable.
  3. The patient’s condition is terminal.
  4. Patient requests death.

 

Another physician must be consulted first, and life must be ended in a medically appropriate way.

 

Other countries which have joined this select group are Belgium, Luxemburg, Switzerland, Thailand.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Germany has restrictive laws regarding euthanasia, where active euthanasia is illegal, but passive euthanasia and assisted suicide have specific legal conditions.

 

Option B. Poland has no legal provision that allows euthanasia.

 

Option C. Austria does not legally permit euthanasia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EUTHANASIA (mercy killing): It means producing painless death of a person suffering from hopelessly incurable and painful disease.

 

In India, passive euthanasia is allowed in rare cases of terminally ill patients, after permission from the high court. Active euthanasia is not allowed in India.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 54-55

questions.text: Dr. Singh, a senior attending physician, is leading a discussion on professional ethics with his residents. He challenges them to think critically about the concept of infamous conduct within the medical profession by presenting a list of actions. He asks the residents to identify which of the listed actions does not typically constitute infamous conduct. Which of the following is not considered infamous conduct in medical ethics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adoption

 

Option D:

 

Adoption does not fall under the category of infamous conduct as it is a legal process of creating a parental relationship and does not pertain to professional medical conduct or ethics.

 

Serious Professional Misconduct (Infamous conduct in professional respect): It is any conduct of the doctor which might reasonably be regarded as disgraceful or dishonorable. Actions that are deemed to be unethical or unprofessional within the medical community.

 

Following are the examples of infamous conduct:

 

  • Adultery (Option B)
  • Advertising (Option C)
  • Abortion (criminal) (Option A)
  • Association with an unqualified person in professional matters
  • Addiction to drugs
  • Alcohol
  • Bribe
  • Covering
  • Dichotomy
  • False certificate.

 

Trial by State Medical Council

 

Punishment - Erasure of Name or warning

 

Erasure of name - The name of the doctor is removed from the medical register.

 

Penal erasure: The main cause is serious professional misconduct; termed as "the professional death sentence". It deprives the practitioner of all the privileges of a registered practitioner.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical practitioners must understand that infamous conduct goes beyond personal morality and is defined by actions that betray professional ethics, trust, and responsibilities towards patients and society.

 

Penal erasure: The main cause is serious professional misconduct; termed as "the professional death sentence".

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 27

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes is scheduled for an elective hernia repair. Upon admission, he is presented with a document to sign, which consents to the surgery and any additional necessary procedures that may be discovered intraoperatively. This type of consent implies that the patient agrees to all aspects of care, including those not specifically mentioned in the document, provided they are in the course of standard treatment. How is this form of consent best described?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Blanket consent

 

Option A:

 

Blanket consent - At the time of admission of patient in the hospital, consent is taken without mentioning anything specifically and assumes it covers almost everything.  It is generally not a valid consent, except in rare emergency situations when it is impractical to obtain specific consent for each potential procedure. In this question this consent will be certainly invalid.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Extension Doctrine - In an obscure case, the doctor should obtain an open consent to use his discretion for additional procedures needed to cope with unanticipated situations that endanger his health.

 

Option C. Paternalism - Is an abuse of medical knowledge so as to distort the doctor-patient relationship in such a way that the patient is deprived of his autonomy, or of his ability to make a rational choice. The doctor does not disclose the nature of the illness and the proposed treatment deprives the right of patient to accept or reject treatment.

 

Option D. Vicarious liability (liability for act of another) - An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees, if such acts occur in the course of the employment and within its scope, by the principle of respondent superior.

 

Conditions must be satisfied:

 

  1. There must be an employer-employee relationship
  2. The employee's conduct must" occur within the scope of his employment
  3. While on the job.

 

Educational objective:

 

Consent can be of two types:

 

  1. Blanket Consent: Very little information provided to the patient. It is generally not a valid consent, except in rare emergency situations.
  2. Informed Consent: When complete information is given to the patient. It is a Valid consent.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 47, 51

questions.text: During a criminal investigation, the police have detained a suspect in connection with a series of assaults. The investigating officer believes that a medical examination of the suspect will provide crucial evidence linked to the crimes. However, the suspect refuses to consent to the examination. The officer seeks legal guidance on compelling a medical examination without the accused's consent. Under which legal provision can the police request a doctor to conduct a medical examination of an accused person without their consent?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sec 51BNSS

 

Option B:

 

Section 51 of BNSS allows for the medical examination of an accused person by a medical practitioner at the request of a police officer. This can be done without the accused's consent if there are reasonable grounds to believe that such an examination will provide evidence regarding the commission of an offence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sec 194 BNSS - This section is related to Police Inquest.

 

Option C. Sec 52 BNSS4 - This section allows for the medical examination of a person accused of Rape by a medical practitioner at the request of a police officer. This can be done without the accused's consent if there are reasonable grounds to believe that such an examination will provide evidence regarding the commission of an offence. This section specifically applies to individuals accused of rape, while Section 51 of the BNSS applies more generally to anyone accused of any crime. 

 

Option D. Sec 196 BNSS - deals with Magistrate Inquest. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to identify the legal provision that empowers law enforcement to conduct a medical examination of an accused person without their consent in the course of a criminal investigation. Understanding Section 51 of BNSS is crucial for medical professionals, especially those working in forensic medicine, as it outlines their role in assisting law enforcement in gathering evidence through medical examination while adhering to legal mandates.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 52

questions.text: In an emergency department, a physician encounters a patient in a critical state following a traumatic accident. The patient is unconscious, and immediate medical intervention is required. There's no opportunity to obtain consent from the patient or their next of kin. Under which section of the BNS is the physician legally protected for performing emergency medical procedures without the patient's consent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sec. 30 BNS 

 

Option D:

 

Sec 30 BNS- deals with cases of emergency, e.g. head injury requiring urgent decompression. It states that any harm caused to a person in good faith, even without the persons consent, is not an offence, if the circumstances are such that it is impossible for that person to signify consent and has no guardian or other person in lawful charge of him from whom it is possible to obtain consent in time for the thing to be done in benefit. In an emergency, the law implies consent. 

 

Consenting Ages for Treatment  

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sec. 25 BNS - An act is not an offence if it isnt intended or known to likely cause death or grievous hurt, and is done with the consent of a person over 18, who agrees to suffer or take the risk of such harm. 

 

Option B. Sec. 27 BNS- An act done in good faith for the benefit of a person under 12 or with mental illness, with the consent of their guardian, is not an offence, even if it causes harm, as long as it is not intended to cause death or grievous hurt.

 

Option C. Sec. 28 BNS - The consent given under fear or misconception is invalid (e.g. under fear of injury, by an insane or intoxicated person, who is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which he gives his consent)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The objective is to understand the legal provisions that protect healthcare providers when they must perform emergency medical procedures without the patient's consent. Section 30 of BNS is crucial in such scenarios, offering legal protection for actions taken in emergencies, highlighting the balance between legal obligations and the imperative to provide urgent medical care.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 53

questions.text: A surgeon faces an urgent situation where an unconscious patient, brought in after a critical injury, requires immediate life-saving surgery. There are no relatives or known associates available to provide consent. By proceeding with the surgery, the surgeon is acting under which principle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Doctrine of implied consent

 

Option B:

 

The doctrine of implied consent is applicable in emergency situations where a patient is incapacitated and unable to provide consent, and immediate medical action is necessary for the patient's survival or to prevent significant harm. It is based on the assumption, that a reasonable person would consent to lifesaving treatment if they were able to. (implied consent, S. 30 BNS).

 

Exceptions to Informed Consent

 

  • Emergencies (30 BNS).

  • Medical examination requested by a police officer of an arrested accused under Sec. 51-53 BNSS

  • Therapeutic privilege

  • Therapeutic waiver

  • Medico-legal postmortems (Sec. 194 BNS)

  • Psychiatric examination or treatment by court order

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Therapeutic privilege - Refers to withholding specific information from a patient when disclosing it is deemed harmful to the patient's immediate health. However, doctor should disclose full information to the competent relative of the patient.

 

Option C. Therapeutic waiver - A competent person who is aware of being entitled to informed consent may give up his right by waiving it.

 

Option D. Doctrine of informed consent - Involves obtaining explicit consent after providing all relevant information about the patient condition/illness, purpose of further testing, natural course of condition & possible complication, risks, benefits, duration & cost of a treatment/ alternative treatment, prognosis and follow up. The information provided to patients should be simple, easy to understand language and list any possible major complications to enable the patient to determine whether to undergo or decline a procedure (informed refusal).

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question aims to elucidate the legal and ethical principles guiding emergency medical care in situations where patient consent cannot be obtained. Understanding the doctrine of implied consent is vital for medical practitioners, as it legitimizes urgent medical interventions in critical situations, ensuring patient welfare while respecting the bounds of legal and ethical medical practice.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 50-51

choices.text: Patient’s contribution towards negligence
Hospital's contribution towards patient’s damage
Responsibility for actions of a colleague
Responsibility of senior for actions of junior

questions.text: A senior surgeon oversees the work of several junior doctors in a busy hospital. One of the junior doctors, while performing a procedure under the guidance of the senior surgeon, makes a significant error leading to patient harm. The hospital administration is reviewing the incident to determine liability and responsibility. Which concept is most relevant in assessing the responsibility of the senior surgeon for the actions of the junior doctor?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Responsibility of senior for actions of junior

 

Option D:

 

The concept of vicarious liability or responsibility pertains to situations where a senior professional (like a surgeon in this case) is held responsible for the actions of their juniors or subordinates. This is based on the principle that the senior staff member is responsible for supervising, training, and overseeing the work of junior staff. In a hospital setting, this often extends to the responsibility for any errors or negligence committed by junior doctors under their supervision.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patient’s contribution towards negligence - Refers to situations where the patient's own actions contribute to the harm they suffer, which is not relevant in this scenario.

 

Option B. Hospital's contribution towards patient’s damage - While hospitals can be held liable for the actions of their employees, this option does not specifically address the relationship between senior and junior medical staff.

 

Option C. Responsibility for actions of a colleague - This would imply equal standing among professionals, which is different from a hierarchical relationship where a senior is responsible for a junior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to understand the concept of vicarious liability, particularly in medical settings. It highlights the legal and ethical responsibility of senior medical professionals for the actions of their junior colleagues, emphasizing the importance of proper supervision and training in clinical practice. This knowledge is crucial in managing risk and ensuring patient safety in healthcare environments.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 47

questions.text: A patient sues a hospital for negligence after suffering complications from a surgical procedure. During the legal proceedings, it is revealed that the patient failed to follow the post-operative care instructions provided by the medical team, which significantly contributed to the complications. The hospital's legal team is considering a defense strategy based on the patient's role in the outcome. Under which category of negligence can the concept of contributory negligence be applied as a defense by the hospital?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Civil negligence

 

Option A:

 

Contributory negligence is a defense in civil negligence cases. It refers to a situation where the plaintiff (patient in this scenario) is found to have contributed to the harm they suffered through their own negligent actions, such as not following medical advice or care instructions. In cases of civil negligence, if contributory negligence is proven, it can reduce or even negate the liability of the defendant (the hospital, in this case).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Criminal negligence - This involves a disregard for the safety and well-being of others, and contributory negligence is typically not a defense in criminal proceedings.

 

Option C. Corporate negligence - This pertains to the failure of a corporation (such as a hospital) to perform its duties adequately, but contributory negligence is more of an individual rather than a corporate defense.

 

Option D. Composite negligence - Composite negligence describes the situation in which, two or more people negligently causes the same damage to a third person. And, the people responsible are referred to as "composite tortfeasors." It does not specifically pertain to the concept of contributory negligence as a defense.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contributory negligence – both patient and doctor are at fault. Two Doctrines are related to contributory negligence –

 

  1. Last clear chance Doctrine”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Doctor” still had the last chance to avoid complications. Here the doctor cannot take the defense.
  2. Avoidable consequences rule”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Patient” had the last chance to avoid complications by timely informing the doctor. Here doctor can take the defense.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 39

choices.text: Eggshell skull rule

questions.text: A patient with a known brittle bone disorder underwent a minor orthopedic surgery. Post-surgery, the patient ignored the doctor's advice to avoid weight-bearing activities and consequently suffered a severe fracture. In a lawsuit against the hospital, the patient claims negligence in the surgical procedure and post-operative care. The hospital's legal counsel is considering a defense based on the patient's own actions contributing to the injury. Which legal principle is most relevant to this defense?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Avoidable consequence rule

 

Option C:

 

The avoidable consequence rule, also known as the doctrine of mitigating damages, applies in cases where the plaintiff (patient) fails to take reasonable action to minimize the damages or harm that resulted from the defendant's (hospital's) alleged negligence. In this scenario, the patient's failure to follow post-operative advice and engaging in activities that exacerbated their condition is a classic example of failing to mitigate damages. Here doctor can take the defense.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Eggshell skull rule - (Thin skull rule) This rule states that defendants must "take their victims as they find them," meaning they are liable even if the plaintiff’s pre-existing condition exacerbates the injury. It does not apply to the patient’s actions post-injury.

 

Option B. Master-servant rule - Pertains to the liability of an employer (master) for the actions of an employee (servant) and is not relevant in this context.

 

Option D. Common knowledge rule - This rule suggests that some facts are so commonly known that they do not require expert testimony. e.g. the doctor will be held responsible for the lack of application of common sense, such as failure to give fluids in dehydration, or failure to give ATS in case of injuries, or failure to apply an antiseptic to an open cut. It is a variant of res ipsa loquitor. In res ipsa loquitor, the patient need not produce evidence as to both the standard of care and specific act or omission. In doctrine of common knowledge, the patient must prove the causative (negligent) act or omission, but he need not produce evidence to establish the standard of care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contributory negligence – both patient and doctor are at fault. Two Doctrines are related to contributory negligence –

 

  1. Last clear chance Doctrine”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Doctor” still had the last chance to avoid complications. Here the doctor cannot take the defense.
  2. Avoidable consequences rule”: Even after the contributory negligence has occurred, the “Patient” had the last chance to avoid complications by timely informing the doctor. Here doctor can take the defense.

 

Note - Good Samaritan doctrine: One who assist another doctor, who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence, unless the assistance is reckless or rash.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 39

choices.text: Res integra
Res gestae
Res ipsa loquitor
Res judicata

questions.text: A patient undergoes abdominal surgery in a hospital. Postoperatively, the patient complains of severe pain and discomfort. Subsequent imaging reveals a pair of surgical scissors left inside the abdomen. The patient files a lawsuit against the hospital for medical negligence. In the legal proceedings, which doctrine is most applicable to this case, where the facts of the incident inherently suggest negligence without the need for extensive evidence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Res ipsa loquitor

 

Option C:

 

The doctrine of "Res ipsa loquitor" (the thing speaks for itself) applies in cases where the nature of the accident is such that it would not ordinarily occur without negligence. In this case, leaving surgical instruments inside a patient's body during surgery is not an event that would typically happen without negligence. Therefore, this doctrine allows the presumption of negligence on the part of the surgical team without requiring the patient to provide extensive proof.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Res integra - This term refers to a matter not previously decided by the courts (a case or a question that has not been examined or passed upon), not specifically relevant to the apparent negligence in this scenario.

 

Option B. Res gestae - Remarks made by the victim at the time of or immediately after the crime are admissible as evidence, e.g. statements made to people at the scene or to the doctor in hospital.

 

Option D. Res judicata - This refers to a matter that has been adjudicated by a competent court and therefore may not be pursued further by the same parties, not relevant in the initial stages of a negligence case i.e. A matter already adjudged and decided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 38, 643

choices.text: Both civil and criminal

questions.text: During a surgical procedure, a patient was scheduled for the amputation of the left leg due to severe diabetic complications. However, due to a series of errors in the pre-operative process, the surgical team mistakenly amputates the patient's right leg. The patient decides to take legal action against the hospital and the surgical team. Under which category can the liability for amputating the wrong limb be considered?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both civil and criminal

 

Option C:

 

Amputating the wrong limb can be considered under both civil and criminal negligence. In civil negligence, the patient can seek compensation for the harm caused due to the breach of duty of care by the healthcare professionals. Criminal negligence might also be applicable if the actions of the healthcare professionals are found to be recklessly indifferent or a gross deviation from the standard of care, showing disregard for the patient's life and safety.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Criminal negligence - Practically limited to cases in which the patient has died. Mostly associated with drunkenness or impaired efficiency due to the use of drugs by doctors. Doctor shows gross incompetency and inattention in the selection and application of remedies, undue interference by him or criminal indifference to the patient’s safety. Sec. 304-A IPC deals with criminal negligence; whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide is punished with imprisonment upto 2 years and with/without fine.

 

Option B. Civil negligence - arises, when a patient, or in case of death, any relative brings suit in a civil court for realization of compensation from his doctor, if he has suffered injury due to negligence OR When doctor brings a civil suit for the realization of his fees from patient or his relatives, who refuse to pay the same, alleging professional negligence.

 

Option D. Contributory negligence - This does not apply as there is no indication that the patient contributed to the mistake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amputating the wrong limb can be considered under both civil and criminal negligence.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 35, 40

questions.text: A nurse in a private clinic was found to have administered the wrong medication to a patient due to a misreading of the prescription, resulting in the patient's death. The legal proceeding against the nurse is based on the charge of causing death by negligence. According to the Indian Penal Code (IPC) Section 304-A, what is the maximum punishment that can be imposed on the Nurse for this act of medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 years

 

Option B:

 

Section 304-A of the IPC prescribes a maximum punishment of up to two years of imprisonment, or with fine, or with both, for causing death by negligence. This section is often invoked in cases of medical negligence leading to a patient's death where the act is not amounting to culpable homicide.

 

Note - The police sometime register the cases of professional negligence deaths under Sec. 304 IPC which is non-bailable offence, whereas if it is registered under Sec. 304-A IPC, the offence is bailable. The basic difference is that in Sec. 304, the act is intentional, while in 304-A, the act is never done with the intention to cause death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sec. 304-A IPC deals with criminal negligence; whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide is punished with imprisonment upto 2 years and with/without fine.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 40

choices.text: He is from a corporate hospital
Negligence is from inadvertent error

questions.text:
As a forensic expert at a medical college you are studying a recent Supreme Court judgment regarding medical negligence to educate medical students about the legal aspects of their profession. The judgment provides crucial clarifications on the circumstances under which a doctor can be charged under Section 304-A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

 

According to this judgment, under what condition can a doctor be charged for medical negligence under Section 304-A?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gross negligence

 

Option D:

 

The Supreme Court's judgment specifies that a doctor can be charged under Section 304-A of the IPC for medical negligence only in cases of 'gross negligence'. Gross negligence is a legal concept that implies a serious, extreme departure from the standard of care that a reasonable, prudent medical professional would follow. It indicates a blatant disregard for the safety and well-being of patients, far beyond what would be considered a mere error or simple negligence. This level of negligence is so severe that it justifies criminal liability under Section 304-A.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. He is from a corporate hospital: The type of hospital where a doctor practices does not influence the applicability of Section 304-A, as it is independent of the workplace environment.

 

Option B. Negligence is from inadvertent error: Inadvertent errors often fall under the category of simple negligence or professional misconduct, not rising to the level of gross negligence required for Section 304-A.

 

Option C. Simple negligence: Simple negligence, while it may have professional and legal ramifications, does not typically meet the threshold for criminal prosecution under Section 304-A.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Supreme Court's judgment specifies that a doctor can be charged under Section 304-A of the IPC for medical negligence only in cases of 'gross negligence' i.e. death of patient due to rash and negligent act. Imprisonment upto 2 years with or without fine.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 40

questions.text: In a medicolegal lecture, a forensic expert is explaining the legal terminology used in medical negligence cases to medical students. The discussion revolves around the role of a patient in a legal action involving medical negligence. In this context, when a patient initiates a civil lawsuit for medical negligence, how is he or she formally referred to in legal terms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plaintiff

 

Option A:

 

The term 'plaintiff' is used to describe a person or entity that initiates a lawsuit in a civil court by filing a complaint against another party (the defendant). In the context of a medical malpractice case, the patient who is suing the healthcare provider is the plaintiff.

 

Some Terminologies

 

  • CIVIL LAW deals with disputes between two individuals or parties. The party bringing the action in a civil case is called "plaintiff". The accused is called "defendant" in both criminal and civil cases.

  • COMMON LAW is made by judges when they deliver decisions in individual cases.

  • CRIMINAL LAW deals with offences which are considered to be against the public interest, such as offences against the person, property, public safety, security of the State, etc. Here the State is a party represented by public prosecutor, and the accused is the other party.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Defendant - The defender or defendant is the party against whom the lawsuit is filed. In a medical malpractice case, this would be the healthcare provider being sued, not the one who files the case.

 

Option C. Defence Lawyer - The defence lawyer in a court case is the attorney who represents the defendant, the person or party accused of a crime or sued in a civil case.

 

Option D. Public prosecutor - The public prosecutor is a legal representative of the state in criminal cases, not in civil litigation like medical malpractice suits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The educational objective of this question is to understand the roles of different parties in civil litigation. The plaintiff is the party who initiates the lawsuit, the defendant is the one against whom the lawsuit is filed, the judge is the one who gives the judgment, and the public prosecutor is involved in criminal cases, not civil cases.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 40, 643

choices.text: Doctrine of Common Knowledge
Res ipsa loquitor
Therapeutic privilege

questions.text: In a legal case involving a patient's medical treatment, the court requires information about the patient's medical condition and treatment history. However, the treating physician is concerned about the ethical and legal aspects of disclosing patient information, which is typically confidential. Under which legal concept can professional secrecy be divulged in a court of law without violating ethical standards?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Privileged communications

 

Option B:

 

Privileged communications in the context of a court of law refer to the legal protection afforded to certain confidential communications, such as those between a doctor and a patient. However, this privilege can be waived under certain circumstances, such as a court order, where the physician may be required to divulge confidential information for the sake of justice.

 

Examples of Privileged Communications

 

  1. Infectious diseases: e.g. If a patient suffering from cholera, typhoid etc is employed as a cook in a hotel, he should not be allowed to work until becomes non-infections; if patient refuses → the doctor can inform the employer.
  2. Servants & employers: e.g. The engine driver suffering from epilepsy, colour blindness etc, should  get it treated before allowed to work, Otherwise Doctor can inform the employer
  3. Venereal disease: e.g. A person suffering from Syphilis is about to marry– first advise not to marry till he cures, otherwise doctor can inform the spouse concerned
  4. Notifiable diseases: Doctor has duty to notify birth, death, infectious diseases to the public health authorities.
  5. Suspected crime.
  6. Patient’s own interest: e.g. doctor may inform the guardian of the patient about the suicidal tendency of patient
  7. Negligence suits against the doctor.
  8. Courts of law

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Doctrine of Common Knowledge - This pertains to knowledge that is assumed to be known by everyone and does not specifically apply to the confidentiality of doctor-patient communications.

 

Option C. Res ipsa loquitor - A legal principle used in negligence cases, implying that the negligence is evident from the nature of the injury or accident. It does not relate to the disclosure of confidential information.

 

Option D. Therapeutic privilege - Involves withholding specific information from a patient if disclosing it is believed to be potentially harmful. It doesn’t directly apply to court disclosures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PRIVILEGED COMMUNICATION: It is a statement made bonafide upon any subject matter by a doctor to the concerned authority, due to his duty to protect the interests of the community or of the State.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 32-33

questions.text: A forensic expert is invited to speak at a medical college about ethical dilemmas in forensic medicine. The expert discusses various international declarations pertinent to medical ethics. A key topic is the Declaration of Helsinki, which the students are asked to identify the focus of. According to the Declaration of Helsinki, what is the primary area of concern?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human experimentation

 

Option B:

 

The Declaration of Helsinki is the relevant international declaration that sets forth ethical guidelines for conducting medical research involving human subjects. It emphasizes the importance of informed consent, the welfare of the participants, and the ethical considerations in medical research.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Organ transplantation: This is the Declaration of Istanbul on Organ Trafficking and Transplant Tourism.

 

Option C. Torture: The Declaration of Tokyo, not Helsinki, addresses issues related to torture.

 

Option D. Physician’s oath: This is related to the Declaration of Geneva, which is a modern version of the Hippocratic Oath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The importance of the Declaration of Helsinki in the context of forensic medicine and toxicology, particularly in relation to the ethical conduct of human research. Understanding these guidelines is essential for professionals involved in medical research to ensure ethical compliance and protect the rights and well-being of research participants.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 297-298

choices.text: Medical Termination of Pregnancy

questions.text: During a seminar on medical ethics, a forensic expert discusses the Declaration of Oslo and its significance in the field. The expert challenges the students to identify the primary focus of the Declaration of Oslo. What is the Declaration of Oslo related to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medical Termination of Pregnancy

 

Option C:

 

The Declaration of Oslo, formulated by the World Medical Association, specifically addresses the ethical considerations surrounding the Medical Termination of Pregnancy. It provides guidance to medical practitioners on how to approach the issue of abortion, considering the legal, ethical, and medical aspects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Torture - Declaration of Tokyo

 

Option B. Capital Punishment - there is no declaration related to this except the declaration of human rights.

 

Option D. Human experimentation - Declaration of Helsinki.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Declaration of Oslo - Highlights the role of medical professionals in addressing ethical issues related to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy, emphasizing the importance of adhering to ethical and legal standards in such sensitive medical decisions.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 297-298

choices.text: Laws governing professional healthcare practice
Customs of courtesy among members of the same profession
Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state
Voluntary code of conduct in medical profession

questions.text: In a lecture on the professional conduct of healthcare workers, a forensic expert is explaining the concepts of medical etiquette and medical ethics to medical students. The expert emphasizes the differences between these two concepts and asks the students to identify the correct description of medical etiquette. What does medical etiquette specifically refer to?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Customs of courtesy among members of the same profession

 

Option B:

 

Medical etiquette refers to the conventional laws and customs of courtesy followed among members of the same profession. It includes how a doctor should interact with colleagues, maintaining a sense of mutual respect and professional courtesy. For example, a common practice under medical etiquette is not to charge another doctor or their family members for professional services.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Laws governing professional healthcare practice: This is more related to legal responsibilities than etiquette.

 

Option C. Moral principles in dealings with patients and the state: These are aspects of medical ethics, not etiquette.

 

Option D. Voluntary code of conduct in medical profession: While this is somewhat accurate, it is more descriptive of medical ethics than etiquette.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical Etiquette Vs Medical Ethics:

questions.text: During an autopsy conducted by a forensic expert at a medical college, the body of a 40-year-old man who died in a hospital is examined. The man was initially hospitalized following a car accident. The autopsy reveals that the man had a pre-existing medical condition that was exacerbated by a delayed surgery due to hospital administrative errors. Additionally, it is found that the man had not been wearing a seatbelt at the time of the accident. In this context, which type of negligence would involve the concept of 'contributory negligence' as a defense?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Civil negligence

 

Option A:

 

‘Contributory negligence' is relevant in cases where both parties (the plaintiff and the defendant) have contributed to the harm or injury. In this scenario, the hospital's delay in surgery (potentially a case of medical negligence) and the man's failure to wear a seatbelt (personal negligence) both contributed to the outcome. This concept is primarily used as a defense in civil negligence cases, where the plaintiff's own negligence is considered in determining liability or damages.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Criminal negligence: This pertains to reckless disregard for the safety of others. Practically limited to cases in which the patient has died. Mostly associated with drunkenness or impaired efficiency due to the use of drugs by doctors. Doctor shows gross incompetency and inattention in the selection and application of remedies, undue interference by him or criminal indifference to the patient’s safety. Sec. 304-A IPC deals with criminal negligence. Contributory negligence is not a defense in criminal cases.

 

Option C. Corporate negligence: This involves negligence by a corporation, like a hospital. It focuses on organizational failures rather than individual actions.

 

Option D. Composite negligence: This occurs when a patient suffers harm due to the negligence of two or more doctors. It involves multiple negligent parties, it does not specifically address the issue of the plaintiff's contributory negligence

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contributory Negligence -

 

Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct, or absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient, or his personal attendant, which combined with the doctor's negligence, contributed to the injury complained of, as a direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

 

If the doctor and the patient are negligent at the same time, it is a good defense for the doctor. The doctor cannot plead contributory negligence, if he fails to give proper instructions.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 39-40

choices.text: Mens rea
Res ipsa loquitor
Res judicata

questions.text: At a district hospital, a forensic expert is called to review a case involving a 30-year-old woman who underwent an appendectomy. Post-surgery, she experienced severe abdominal pain and subsequent investigations revealed a surgical sponge left inside her abdomen. Due to this, she developed a severe infection leading to extended hospitalization. The woman has filed a lawsuit against the operating surgeon. In this case, which legal principle suggests that the burden of proof for demonstrating the absence of negligence rests with the doctor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Res ipsa loquitor

 

Option B:

 

Ordinarily, the task of proving negligence rests upon the plaintiff (the person who is a person who brings a case against the alleged accused). In medical Negligence cases, the patient will be plaintiff and doctor will be accused. So usually, the responsibility to prove negligence will lie with the patient.

 

There are, however, certain cases, when the negligence is so obvious (Res Ipsa Loquitor) that plaintiff need not prove anything.

 

Res ipsa loquitur ("the thing speaks for itself") means that the nature of injury to patient is such that it in itself proves that Doctor was negligent. The patient does not have to prove anything further. E.g. scissors left in Abdomen is an obvious negligence on the part of doctors and other medical staff involved.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mens rea: This term refers to the mental state of intending to commit a crime or knowing that one's action or lack of action would result in a crime. It is not directly applicable in the context of medical negligence.

 

Option C. Res judicata: This principle means that a case has already been judged and cannot be pursued further in court. It does not apply to the initial determination of negligence.

 

Option D. Vicarious liability: This involves a party being held responsible for the actions of another, such as an employer for an employee’s actions. While relevant in some medical negligence cases, it does not shift the burden of proof regarding negligence.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

'Res ipsa loquitur' in medical negligence cases, particularly in scenarios where the negligence is apparent and requires the defendant (usually the medical professional or institution) to prove the absence of negligence.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 45

choices.text: Examine and prescribe as appropriate
Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present
Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery
Examine but not prescribe

questions.text: In a community health center, a 13-year-old boy presents to a general practitioner with complaints of a sore throat. He has come to the clinic alone, without any adult accompanying him. The general practitioner is considering the appropriate legal course of action in this situation. What should the general practitioner legally do in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Examine and prescribe as appropriate.

 

Option A:

 

Legally, a general practitioner can examine and prescribe treatment to a minor if they believe the child is capable of understanding the nature and implications of the treatment, a concept known as 'Gillick competence'. In this scenario, the 13-year-old boy's capacity to seek medical help on his own for a sore throat suggests a level of maturity and understanding. Therefore, the doctor can legally examine the boy and prescribe the appropriate treatment without necessarily having an adult present.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Refuse to see him unless a responsible adult is present: is not typically the best choice because doctors often prioritize the immediate health needs of the patient, especially if the patient is above the age of 12 and capable of understanding their condition.

 

Option C. Write to the parent asking them to come to the surgery: may cause delays in providing timely medical care to the 13-year-old patient. The presence of a guardian is not typically required if the patient is above 12 and capable of understanding their condition.

 

Option D. Examine but not prescribe: is not ideal because it may leave the patient without necessary treatment. It’s often better to examine and, if needed, prescribe treatment, especially if the patient is above 12 and capable of understanding their condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimum age at which a person can give consent:

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman undergoes a complex elective cosmetic surgery at a private clinic. Prior to the procedure, the surgeon thoroughly explains the potential risks and complications, including the possibility of postoperative infection and scarring. The patient signs a detailed informed consent form acknowledging these risks. Unfortunately, she develops an infection post-surgery, which is promptly treated, but she decides to sue for negligence. In this case, what type of negligence can the patient's signed informed consent form potentially defend against?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Civil negligence

 

 

Option A:

 

In this scenario, the patient's informed consent, which she provided before undergoing elective cosmetic surgery, can serve as a defense against a civil negligence claim. Informed consent means that the patient was made fully aware of the risks and potential complications of the procedure and agreed to proceed. This understanding and agreement can mitigate liability in a civil lawsuit, as the patient had acknowledged and accepted the potential risks, such as infection and scarring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Criminal Negligence: In criminal negligence, consent is typically not a defense, as criminal negligence implies a higher degree of recklessness or disregard for safety.

 

Option C. Both of the above: Informed consent is primarily relevant as a defense in civil negligence cases.

 

Option D. None of the above: Informed consent is indeed a valid defense in civil negligence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between civil and criminal negligence -

choices.text: Informed consent
Implied consent
Blanket Consent
Both B and C

questions.text:
A patient is brought into the emergency room after a severe car accident. The patient is unconscious and in critical condition, with multiple injuries. In this situation, the healthcare team may need to perform various surgical procedures, such as:

 

  • Emergency surgery to stop internal bleeding.
  • Orthopedic surgery to repair broken bones.
  • Neurosurgery to relieve pressure on the brain.
  • Plastic surgery to address facial injuries.
  • Thoracic surgery to treat lung injuries.

 

Given the urgency of the situation and the patient's inability to provide specific consent, the healthcare team may ask a family member for consent to perform any necessary surgeries to stabilize and treat the patient's injuries, without giving details on specific type of surgery. This is a type of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blanket consent

 

Option C:

 

Since detailed information on type of surgery is not provided to family member, it is a blanket consent.

 

Blanket (open) consent: The consent taken at the time of admission and practiced in most hospitals that cover almost everything a doctor might do to a patient without mentioning anything specific. It is of questionable legal validity, except in cases of emergencies.

 

Note - Consent is invalid if:

 

  • It is not an informed consent.
  • Given for committing a crime or an illegal act, such as criminal abortion.
  • Obtained by misrepresentation or fraud.
  • Given by one who had no legal capacity to give it, e.g. a minor or an insane person.

 

In an emergency, the law implies consent. An emergency is defined as a medical situation, such as to render immediate treatment advisable either to save life or to safeguard health.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Informed consent: Since detailed information on type of surgery is not provided to family member, it is not an informed consent

 

Option B. Implied consent: Since the permission for doing surgery is specifically taken, it is an expressed consent (not implied)

 

Option D. Both B and C: This cannot be the answer as B choice is wrong.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Consent can be of two types based on how much information provided on how much information provided:

choices.text: Medical institutions can only be held responsible for the actions of their employed medical professionals if the institution had direct knowledge of the negligence
Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence, as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment
Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals are acting as independent contractors within a medical institution
Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved has a valid license to practice

questions.text: In the realm of medical practice, the principle of vicarious liability plays a crucial role in determining legal responsibility. Which of the following statements best exemplifies the concept of vicarious liability in cases of medical negligence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vicarious liability extends to situations where medical professionals, acting as independent contractors within a medical institution.

 

Option C:

 

Vicarious liability can extend to cases involving independent contractors if certain conditions are met. While it's more common to apply vicarious liability to employees, there are situations where independent contractors can also trigger vicarious liability, especially if they are integrated into the institution's operations to a significant extent.

 

It's important to note that vicarious liability doesn't absolve the individual employee or agent from personal liability. Both the individual who committed the wrongful act and the employer or principal can be held legally responsible, but the doctrine ensures that the victim has a better chance of receiving appropriate compensation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Medical institutions can only be held responsible for actions of their employed medical professionals if institution had direct knowledge of negligence.

 

Vicarious liability is not dependent on institution's knowledge of negligence. Employer can be held responsible for the actions of their employees or agents (within the scope of their employment), regardless of the employer's knowledge of those actions.

 

Option B. Vicarious liability does not apply when medical professionals commit gross negligence, as such actions are considered beyond the scope of their employment.

 

Vicarious liability applies as long as negligent actions occurred within the scope of employment, irrespective of whether the negligence is considered "gross" or not. Nature of negligence, whether ordinary or gross, does not matter for applying vicarious liability.

 

Option D. Vicarious liability mandates that medical institutions are immune to legal action if the medical professional involved had a valid license to practice.

 

Possession of a valid license doesn't exempt medical institutions from vicarious liability. Even if a licensed professional commits negligence, the principle of vicarious liability can still hold the employer liable for the actions of their employee or agent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the context of medical negligence, vicarious liability means that a healthcare institution, such as a hospital or clinic, can be held legally responsible for the actions or omissions of its medical professionals (doctors, nurses, etc.) if those actions occurred within the scope of their employment. This holds true even if the institution itself did not directly contribute to the negligence. However, certain conditions, such as the actions occurring within the employment relationship and within the scope of duties, need to be satisfied for vicarious liability to apply.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 47

questions.text: In a complex medical malpractice lawsuit, Amit, a 40-year-old patient, underwent a routine laparoscopic cholecystectomy at a reputable hospital. The surgery was performed by Dr. Sheela, a highly skilled surgeon. However, during the procedure, an unforeseen event occurred. Amit sustained a deep laceration to her abdominal aorta, a major blood vessel, which required immediate vascular surgery to repair. Despite the seriousness of the injury, Amit's legal team encountered difficulties in identifying the precise cause of the aortic laceration or pinpointing a specific act of negligence. There were no clear breaches of established surgical protocols, and Dr. Sheela's credentials and experience were impeccable. In the context of this challenging case, which legal doctrine might Amit's legal team invoke to establish negligence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) "Res Ipsa Loquitur"

 

Option C:

 

Injury to abdominal aorta is not an expected complication of cholecystectomy. It is so obvious that surgeon would have been grossly negligent, only then the aorta could have been injured in this case. Since negligence is obvious, the legal doctrine of "res ipsa loquitur" may be invoked.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. "Respondeat Superior": It is a legal doctrine that holds employers liable for the actions of their employees if those actions occur within the scope of employment.

 

Option B. "Res Judicata": It is a legal principle that prevents the same matter or claim from being litigated again after it has already been adjudicated by a competent court.

 

Option D. "Res Gestae": It refers to statements or acts that are so closely associated with a particular event that they are considered part of the event itself. It is not directly related to establishing negligence in medical malpractice cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Res ipsa loquitur:

 

  • It is a Latin phrase for "the thing speaks for itself."

  • Common knowledge Doctrine: Negligence is so obvious that it does not require expert testimony or specific evidence to establish a breach of the standard of care.

  • Obvious Negligence: The event is unusual and wouldn't occur without negligence

  • The defendant had control over the situation or object that caused the injury.

  • The plaintiff didn't contribute to the injury.

 

Ref: Reddy 33/e. Pg 45
